title: William Bowra
text:
William Bowra (1752 – 7 May 1820) was an English <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er who played regularly for Kent teams from 1768 until 1788 and then for Sussex until 1792. He had 50 known first-class appearances between 1775 and 1792. His name was pronounced "Borra".
Bowra is thought to have been born at <a href="Sevenoaks">Sevenoaks</a>, <a href="Kent">Kent</a>. In a "Hampshire Chronicle" report of a 1775 game, his name is spelt "Bower". Bowra was a useful batsman who was employed by <a href="John%20Frederick%20Sackville%2C%203rd%20Duke%20of%20Dorset">John Frederick Sackville, 3rd Duke of Dorset</a> as a gamekeeper. He is believed to have been an outstanding fielder in close positions as a great many catches were credited to him.
The Duke of Dorset was a great admirer of his play and the sources have recorded, perhaps as an anecdote, that Dorset used to sit on the railing round the <a href="Vine%20Cricket%20Ground">Sevenoaks Vine</a> ground to watch him bat, often exclaiming: "Bravo, my little Bowra".
Bowra subsequently played for the Brighton team during 1790–1792 and once made 60 not out for Brighton v <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a>. At this time he was perhaps employed on one of Dorset’s estates in Sussex. He returned to <a href="Knole%20House">Knole House</a> in 1807, again as gamekeeper, and it is believed he stayed there till his death in 1820.
